metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Large aperture scintillometer of Daman Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) at Daman Superstation in the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. There were two types of LASs at Daman Superstation: BLS900 and RR-RSS460, produced by Germany. The north tower was set up with the BLS900 receiver and the RR-RSS460 transmitter, and the south tower was equipped with the BLS900 transmitter and the RR-RSS460 receiver. The site (north: 100.379° E, 38.861° N; south: 100.369° E, 38.847° N) was located in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The underlying surfaces between the two towers were corn, orchard, and greenhouse. The elevation is 1556 m. The effective height of the LASs was 24.1 m, and the path length was 1854 m. The data were sampled 1 minute at both BLS900 and RR-RSS460.
The raw data acquired at 1 min intervals were processed and quality controlled. The data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods, in which sensible heat flux was iteratively calculated by combining Cn2 with meteorological data according to the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory. The main quality control steps were as follows: (1) The data were rejected when Cn2 exceeded the saturated criterion (BLS900：Cn2>7.25E-14，RR-RSS460：Cn2>7.84 E-14). (2) The data were rejected when the demodulation signal was small (BLS900：Average X Intensity<1000；RR-RSS460：Demod>-20mv). (3) The data were rejected when collected during precipitation. (4) The data were rejected if collected at night when weak turbulence occurred (u* was less than 0.1 m/s). In the iteration process, the universal functions of Thiermann and Grassl (1992) and Andreas (1988) were selected for BLS900 and RR-RSS460, respectively. Detailed can refer to Liu et al. (2011, 2013). Due to instrument adjustment and inadequate power supply, the date of missing data for the large aperture scintillator is: 2021.05.15-2021.06.10.
Several instructions were included with the released data. (1) The data were primarily obtained from BLS900 measurements, and missing flux measurements from the BLS900 instrument were substituted with measurements from the RR-RSS460 instrument. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) The dataset contained the following variables: Date/time (yyyy/m/d h:mm), the structural parameter of the air refractive index (Cn2, m-2/3), and the sensible heat flux (H, W/m^2). In this dataset, a time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30, and the data were stored in *.xlsx format. 
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is a scintillometer and how is it used in data collection for surface process observations?
Definition.Answer: A scintillometer is an instrument used to measure the turbulence of air, which can provide data on heat fluxes. In the context of surface process observations, it is used to collect flux data by measuring changes in air refractive index, which are related to heat and moisture exchange between the surface and the atmosphere.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets in understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Definition.Answer: Long-term datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange are crucial for understanding the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems as they provide comprehensive insights into the environmental dynamics, support the evaluation of ecological stability, and assist in achieving sustainable development goals such as carbon neutrality in these regions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using a large aperture scintillometer at the Heihe River Basin compare to those using an eddy covariance system in terms of capturing energy and water vapor fluxes?
Comparison.Answer: The large aperture scintillometer at the Heihe River Basin captures energy and water vapor fluxes using a one-minute sampling frequency, focusing on the sensible heat flux through quality-controlled data. The eddy covariance system, on the other hand, provides half-hourly turbulent flux data, including carbon and methane fluxes, and integrates auxiliary data from automatic weather stations, offering a comprehensive approach to observing fluxes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced by oasis–desert systems in the Tarim River basin compare to those in the Heihe River Basin regarding ecological environment degradation?
Comparison.Answer: Both the Tarim River basin and the Heihe River Basin face challenges related to ecological environment degradation, such as land desertification and river drying. However, the Tarim River basin is highlighted for frequent dust storms and crises like the drying up of the Aral Sea, while the Heihe River Basin's challenges are observed in the context of the broader impact on oasis–desert interactions and the importance of maintaining ecological balance for sustainable development.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the quality control procedures used in the data collection for the large aperture scintillometer and the eddy covariance system?
Comparison.Answer: The quality control procedure for the large aperture scintillometer involves steps like discarding saturated data and weak signal data, as well as removing data during precipitation and weak turbulence conditions. For the eddy covariance system, the procedure includes data collection, processing, and archiving, with comprehensive datasets that include hydrometeorological and vegetation parameters, indicating a more integrated approach to data quality assurance.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of large aperture scintillometers contribute to understanding the energy exchange processes in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of large aperture scintillometers, such as BLS900 and RR-RSS460, allows for detailed observation of sensible heat flux in arid regions. By deploying these instruments at different locations and heights, researchers can infer energy exchange processes and understand how they affect ecological stability and agricultural productivity in oasis-desert systems.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be inferred from the process of ensuring data quality and reliability in long-term observational datasets within arid ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in ensuring data quality and reliability include managing and correcting for data saturation, weak signal intensity, precipitation interference, and weak turbulence conditions. Instrument maintenance, power supply issues, and signal problems can also cause data gaps, as seen in the missing data period from May 15 to June 10, 2021, highlighting the complexities of data management in such environments.

Interpretation.Question: How do supplementary data such as vegetation and soil parameters enhance the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Supplementary data like vegetation and soil parameters provide context to the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets, allowing for a more comprehensive understanding of the oasis-desert interactions. These additional data help in interpreting the effects of ecological and environmental variables on fluxes and support the goal of achieving sustainable oasis development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for extensive quality control steps during the data collection process in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for extensive quality control steps arises due to various challenges such as instrument saturation, weak signal intensities, precipitation events, and weak turbulent conditions, which can affect the reliability and accuracy of data collected from instruments like large aperture scintillometers in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of specific stability functions during the iterative calculation of heat flux in oasis–desert areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of specific stability functions is influenced by the type of instrument used and the theoretical models that best fit the environmental conditions. For instance, different stability functions may be chosen based on the characteristics of the large aperture scintillometers (like BLS900 or RR-RSS460) and their suitability for specific atmospheric stability conditions described in theories by Thiermann and Grassl or Andreas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing a comprehensive quality control procedure in data collection methods for oasis-desert ecosystem studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a comprehensive quality control procedure in data collection methods for oasis-desert ecosystem studies results in more accurate and reliable data. This is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences may arise from the integration of scintillometer and eddy covariance systems in capturing energy and carbon flux data in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of scintillometer and eddy covariance systems in capturing energy and carbon flux data in arid regions allows for a thorough and nuanced understanding of energy dynamics and gas exchanges, which is significant for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and protecting ecological stability.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations influence the understanding of hydrometeorological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations enhances the understanding of hydrometeorological processes by providing comprehensive datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes as well as auxiliary data on vegetation and soil parameters, supporting research on ecological and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect long-term observational data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term data collection is crucial to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area, support ecological security, and ensure sustainable development of oases. This quantitative understanding helps recognize oasis–desert interactions, which is significant for protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why are detailed quality control procedures necessary when processing data collected from oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Detailed quality control procedures are necessary to ensure the accuracy and reliability of data, which involves removing saturated data, weak signal data, and data during precipitation or weak turbulence conditions. This is crucial for maintaining the integrity of datasets used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes managed and shared to support research on oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational datasets are managed through a process that includes data collection, processing, and archiving. These datasets are made freely available and shared via platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center to support research and understanding of oasis-desert ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to integrate and process hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters data in arid regions to study energy and carbon exchange?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and other related parameters, are acquired from automatic weather stations with a specified average period. These data are integrated with vegetation and soil parameters in a comprehensive dataset for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate measurement of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations provide hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles with a 10-minute average period, supplemented by groundwater table data.

Enablement.Question: What are the primary challenges that need to be addressed to ensure high-quality data collection in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which are particularly prevalent in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, Aral Sea basin, and Lake Urmia basin.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters provides a comprehensive dataset that supports a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This integration is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and is significant for protecting ecological stability and the socioeconomic development of oases.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in maintaining accurate and continuous data from large aperture scintillometers in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining accurate and continuous data from large aperture scintillometers in arid regions could be due to factors such as instrument maintenance needs, power supply issues, and signal problems. Additionally, environmental factors like precipitation and weak turbulence conditions can affect data quality, requiring rigorous quality control and data processing steps.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have for the utility of long-term oasis–desert ecosystem data in achieving carbon neutrality goals?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect that long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems will provide critical insights into the balance of these systems, supporting the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality. Such data is anticipated to help in understanding ecological interactions and ensuring ecological security and sustainable development of oasis regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might datasets from oasis–desert systems require comprehensive quality control procedures before being shared?
Expectation.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert systems might require comprehensive quality control procedures due to the complexity of the data, which includes various flux measurements and auxiliary parameters. Ensuring data reliability involves removing saturated data, weak signal data, and periods of instrument malfunction, which are critical for obtaining accurate and meaningful results for further analysis and sharing.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the data collection techniques used for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection techniques involve the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for measuring turbulent flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data. These methods are comprehensive and cover a wide range of parameters, which is crucial for understanding the oasis–desert interactions and supporting sustainable development.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges encountered in maintaining long-term observation datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges include ecological degradation, such as drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms, which can affect data continuity. Additionally, logistical issues like instrument maintenance and power supply can lead to data gaps, as observed with scintillometer data missing due to such problems.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the quality control steps are applied to ensure the accuracy of data collected from large aperture scintillometers.
Assertion.Answer: The quality control steps for data from large aperture scintillometers include removing saturated data based on specific thresholds for the refractive index structure parameter (Cn2), excluding data with weak demodulation signal strength, eliminating data during precipitation, and discarding data under stable conditions with weak turbulence. These steps help maintain the accuracy and reliability of the data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting long-term observational data in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in collecting long-term observational data in oasis-desert ecosystems include dealing with issues such as ecological environment degradation, drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These conditions can impact the stability and continuity of data collection in these regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange are integrated and processed over long periods.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange are integrated and processed through a combination of data collection, processing, and archiving methods. Observations are made using systems like eddy covariance and scintillometers, supplemented by hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters. The datasets are then processed to ensure quality and shared through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the quality control procedures used in data collection methods for large aperture scintillometer data in arid regions, focusing on the rejection criteria for data points.
Request/Directive.Answer: The quality control procedures for large aperture scintillometer data involve several rejection criteria: (1) Data with saturated Cn2 values are removed (BLS900: Cn2>7.25E-14, RR-RSS460: Cn2>7.84 E-14). (2) Data with weak demodulation signal intensity are discarded (BLS900: Average X Intensity<1000; RR-RSS460: Demod>-20mv). (3) Data collected during precipitation are excluded. (4) Data under stable conditions with weak turbulence (u* less than 0.1m/s) are rejected.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observation in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensified land desertification, and frequent dust storms, especially in inland river basins in arid and semiarid regions like the Tarim River basin, Aral Sea basin, and Lake Urmia basin.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, considering the current data collection methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets include establishing more land surface flux and meteorological stations in oasis–desert areas, utilizing long-term observations for better quantitative understanding, and integrating datasets with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Leveraging data from superstations and ordinary stations, as well as ensuring data archiving and sharing through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, can also enhance dataset comprehensiveness.
